lessons.title: IP vs MAC vs hostname
lessons.summary: Why devices have multiple identities on a LAN.
body: An IP address is usually assigned by DHCP and can change over time.
A MAC address is a hardware identifier on the local network (more stable for tracking devices).
A hostname is a human-readable label a device may announce (DHCP, mDNS, or DNS).
For inventory, MAC is typically the most stable key; IP is metadata.
what_to_do_now: Pick one device and give it a friendly name.
Notice if any device’s IP changes across hours.

lessons.title: DHCP & IP churn
lessons.summary: Why the same device can show different IPs.
body: Most home networks use DHCP to lease IPs to devices.
Leases expire, devices disconnect/reconnect, or the router reassigns addresses.
That’s why inventory tools track devices by MAC and show IP history separately.
what_to_do_now: Open a device and look at its IP history lane.
If a device is critical (NAS/AP), consider reserving its IP in your router.

lessons.title: Ports & services
lessons.summary: What it means when a port is open on your LAN.
body: A port is like a numbered ‘door’ a service listens on.
An ‘open’ port means the device is accepting connections on that port from the LAN.
On a home LAN, open ports are often normal; the goal is understanding, not panic.
what_to_do_now: Click a device and review its Exposure section.
If you don’t recognize a service, search within the app for that port number.

lessons.title: mDNS (Bonjour) basics
lessons.summary: How devices advertise names and capabilities on a LAN.
body: mDNS lets devices announce names like *.local without a central DNS server.
Services are advertised as types like _airplay._tcp or _googlecast._tcp.
Service types indicate capability categories (streaming, printing, smart home).
what_to_do_now: Look at a device’s mDNS services and guess its category.
Use mDNS service types as evidence when classifying unknown devices.

lessons.title: SSDP/UPnP discovery
lessons.summary: Why TVs and media devices often show up via SSDP.
body: SSDP is a LAN discovery protocol often used by media devices (DLNA) and some routers.
Seeing SSDP responses usually means the device is advertising a description URL on the LAN.
This is different from ‘port forwarding’—it’s about discovery inside your network.
what_to_do_now: Open a device with SSDP and note the server string.
Use SSDP evidence to classify unknown devices.
